qas.question: What is the only divisor besides 1 that a prime number can have?
What are numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 3 or more numbers called?
What theorem defines the main role of primes in number theory?
Any number larger than 1 can be represented as a product of what?

answers.text: product of primes that is unique up to ordering
primes that is unique up to ordering

qas.question: Why must one be excluded in order to preserve the uniqueness of the fundamental theorem?

answers.text: because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization
one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization
can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization
one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization
because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization

qas.question: What is the only divisor besides 1 that a product can have?
What are numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 6 or more numbers called?
What can any number larger than 6 can be represented as?
A number larger than -3 can be represented as a product of what?

plausible_answers.text: because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization

qas.question: Why must -1 be excluded in order to preserve the uniqueness of the fundamental theorem?

context: A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><b5_0>itself<b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>composite number<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. For example, 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only positive integer factors, whereas 6 is composite because it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 and 6. <a2_0><b7_0>The <a2_1><a2_3><a2_4>fundamental theorem of <a2_2>arithmetic<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> establishes the central role of <a1_3>primes<a1_3/> in number theory: any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as <a3_0><b8_0>a <a3_1>product of <a3_2><a3_3><a3_4>primes<b8_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_0/> that is unique up to ordering<a3_4/><a3_1/>. The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime <a4_0><a4_4><b9_0>because <a4_1><a4_3>one <a4_2>can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization<b9_0/><a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, e.g., 3, 1 · 3, 1 · 1 · 3, etc. are all valid factorizations of 3.
